00018 /*
00019  * TypeTopicCounts.h
00020  * The Main class so to say which maintains the
00021  * Word-Topic counts table (n(t,w)). This is just a wrapper
00022  * around the TopicCounts structure that gives a
00023  * sparse matrix view out of sparse vector(TopicCounts)
00024  * Also note that the words are not strings but indexes
00025  * which can be lookedup in the dictionary if needed.
00026  * The protobuf file also stores the word indexes instead
00027  * of words to save space
00028  *
00029  * It basically has 2 types of initializations:
00030  * 1. Directly from the words & Topics files (initialize_from_docs) Slow
00031  * 2. From a binary dump produced by the dump() method (initialize_from_dump) Faster
00032  *
00033  * The basic structure maintains the for each unique word
00034  * found in the corpus/dictionary the number of times
00035  * each topic has been assigned. It supports multithreaded
00036  * access with a per word locking granularity. Its designed
00037  * to do fast updates. The locks are classified into read
00038  * and write locks to minimize contention. The updates/setters
00039  * hold a write lock and block further reads and writes on the
00040  * locked word. The get_counts methods hold a read lock and allow
00041  * other reads which are way more frequent as there are multiple
00042  * sampler threads trying to read the topic counts whereas there
00043  * is only a single thread updating in the single machine case
00044  * and 2 background threads and the updater thread
00045  * in the case of multi-machine code. Since update locks are
00046  * expensive, we try to optimize updates.
00047  *
00048  * The basic access pattern is assumed to be:
00049  * Do get_counts on the reqd word.
00050  * Update the counts thread locally and
00051  * Update the shared table.
00052  *
00053  * So the basic design aim is to support multi-threaded reads and
00054  * almost single threaded updates
00055  *
00056  * This also maintains the sum of topic counts across the corpus (n(t))
00057  * However, there is no locking involved while doing this as it is
00058  * declared as an array of tbb::atomics.
00059  *
00060  *  Created on: 24 Mar, 2009
00061  *      
00062  */
00063
